title: Information about typeface Chaparral
content:
Hello everybody,

I´m a design student from Augsburg in Germany. At school i´m in a typographic project. The students may analise a typeface (their structure, composition and so on). I decided to deal with Chaparral. But i couldn´t find much about that typeface. I also need some information about Carol Twombly who created Chaparral. Maybe one of you can help me. Any advice would further.

Thank you for any information  
Regina
author: ginagrandiosa

comments.content: Lubricate thoroughly before you proceed. That Chaparral looks to have some nasty edges.
In that project it doesn´t matter if the typeface is well-conceived. I decided to take Chaparral because of its characteristic features. The results of our studies are important.

Hi Regina! [Ignore Claus, he’s just making fun of a certain misspelled word ;-)] For [Carol Twombly](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Carol%20Twombly), consult the wiki. And check out [this thread](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/32680). Here are a couple of quotes on Chaparral, from typophiles. It seems to be quite a polarising face. I, for one, like it very much (using it for my stationery & stuff). I keep trying to use it and it always seems to fall short. I can’t articulate why. — [Patty](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39592#comment-244492) Chaparral […] could end up as a standard children’s font for me. — [Malte](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42632#comment-262630) Chaparral is hard to use well, for sure. — [Will](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39592#comment-244574) Chaparral is probably the only slab that has optical sizes. I do have to say that it’s really versatile, though it’s not exactly a Scala-kind-of-workhorse. — [Bram](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/28288#comment-159471) What ONE typeface would you have rather not exist? Chaparral. Ok, you beat me up for this one. — [Thomas](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36352#comment-222258) Bringhurst does mention Chaparral in his list of types. And since he mentions so relatively few types, that means he gave it his seal of approval. — [Reed](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/29407#comment-168386) (Bringhurst’s _The Solid Form of Language_ is set in Chaparral.) Plus: some unisonous thoughts about pairing: Auto is sort of a Chaparral Sans. — [Stewf](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38561#comment-236149) The informal shapes of Chaparral will probably play real nice with Auto. — [Carl](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831143200/http:/www.typophile.com/node/19326#comment-118785) F
Thank you very much. That helps a lot.

Don't trust any supposedly informed speculation/information about Carol from anyone who can't even spell her name correctly, is all I can say.

T
Did Carol Twombly ever tell something about the typeface - maybe about the development and her motivations?
